entry.title: Wien's law step by step
entry.summary:
The Wein's displacement law is obtained from Planck's law. Hereafter, I will show how it cam be found.

\begin{equation} \label{eq1} B(T,\lambda) = \frac{2hc^{2}}{\lambda^{5}(exp(\frac{hc}{kT})-1)} \end{equation}

By simplicity, let's define \(\alpha\equiv 2hc^{2}\) and \(\gamma\equiv \frac{hc}{kT}\)

So, the equation \ref{eq1} becomes

\begin{equation} \label{eq2} B(T, \lambda) = D\lambda^{-5}(exp(\frac{B}{\lambda})-1)^{-1} \end{equation}

But what we want to find? We are interested to find in which wavelength occur the maximum emissivity. For it, we need to make \(\frac{\partial B}{\partial \lambda}=0\).

\begin{equation} \begin{split} \frac{\partial B}{\partial \lambda}=D\lambda^{6-}(exp(\frac{B}{\lambda})-1) [-5+ \\ B\lambda^{-1}(exp(\frac{B}{\lambda})-1)^{-1}exp(\frac{B}{\lambda})] =0 \end{split} \label{eq3} \end{equation}

The solution of equation \ref{eq3} is getting doing the factor inside of brackets equal to zero.

\begin{equation} -5+ B\lambda^{-1}(exp(\frac{B}{\lambda})-1)^{-1}exp(\frac{B}{\lambda}) =0 \label{eq4} \end{equation}

After to reorder all factors in \ref{eq4}, we will get the equation bellow.

\begin{equation} \lambda[\exp(\frac{B}{\lambda})(\frac{B}{\lambda}-5)+5]=0 \label{eq5} \end{equation}

Once that \(\lambda\) is different of zero, the factor inside of brackets has to be zero.

\begin{equation} exp(\frac{B}{\lambda})(\frac{B}{\lambda}-5)+5=0 \label{eq6} \end{equation}

The equation \ref{eq6} is a transcendental equation, it means that this equation isn't possible to solve by traditional way. By simplicity, we will define \(g\equiv \frac{B}{\lambda}\). So, the least equation becomes

\begin{equation} exp(\frac{B}{\lambda})(\frac{B}{\lambda}-5)+5=0 \label{eq6} \end{equation}

(I will finish it soon as possible.)

entry.title: AERONET on Brazil
entry.summary:
Actually, on Brazil there are nine AERONET station in operation. Five from these stations are placed in Amazon Region and the four others are spread out over remaining territory. The AOT data measured may be classified like level 1.5 and 2.0. This classification is associated with algorithm applied to process data.

In figure, the circles indicates where each station is placed. The yellow and green colors are used to indicate the availability of data level 1.5 and 2.0, respectively.

entry.title: Aerosol Data Validation on Brazil
entry.summary:
On Oct. 28, 2011 the Suomi National Polar-orbiting Partnership spacecraft was launched. It is a result of mutual cooperation between NASA and NOAA. This spacecraft is composed by five sensors to monitor Earth System. One of them is Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS). One possible utility is to monitor Aerosol Optical Thickness.

In Brazil, the National Institute For Space Research is data receiver of environmental satellite data. In particular, my job is to evaluate performance of Aerosol Optical Thickness (AOT) on the Brazil. The core of procedure is to compare AOT retrieved by VIIRS with AOT measured in AERONET sites and with AOT retrieved by MODIS sensor. This project is under supervise of Dr. Sievert.

The figure above shows spatial difference for VIIRS and MODIS AOT data on June, 2014. The result collection is hosted in AOT Results.
